title: Delay Javascript/Typescript lint
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

When I type code, I don't need a bunch of squiggly lines to pop up to tell me that "namesp", "namespa" and "namespac" are not a thing. I'd like to delay the lint until the time a file is saved.

Unfortunately the list of settings is bloated and unorganized, I'm not sure how I'm supposed to find that functionality in there or if it even exists.

title: PR: Add cli arguments to run the electron build as a webserver backend (headless) Replacement for #81474
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
This issue is a part of: #81474 
<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
it offers a secund way to serve vscode-online via the electron build it self without additional nodejs server and additional vscode-web code build.


## Goals
- could reduce the overall maintance overhead if we go with a single code base for both cases.
- don't clashes with currrent vscode-web team
- is maybe faster implamented and will reduce in faster release cycles.

## Create a secund Branch based on electron.
The idea is to combine both to contribute a code-cli --server flag to run headless and get used via the browser.

- We know from the microsoft ai research team that we can run electron headless
```
/*
Now to force Electron in software mode in the cloud, Chrome blacklisted GPUs from running. You
 cannot run it on Azure, AWS, Google Cloud. so you need to disable that by doing the following:
*/
const { app } = require(‘electron’)
app.commandLine.appendSwitch(‘ — ignore-gpu-blacklist’)
//To not render the Electron window, you just hide it when constructing it:
new BrowserWindow({ width: 1280, height: 800, show: false })
```
- We know from the electron team that we can start external reachable server services via child process spawn
```js
const { fork } = require('child_process')
const ps = fork(`${__dirname}/server.js`)
// The __dirname variable is required if you want to deploy on a binary build otherwise the script won’t be reached properly.
```

title: Switch to polling for watching changes on config files
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/81579 got answered by @sandy081 

```
This is to watch changes for user configuration data in VS Code.

Settings
Keybindings
Snippets
It's also to watch log files when output panel is opened.

We do not watch the whole user home directory, but code/User folder under user home directory. code/User folder is the one created by VS Code for storing above user data.
```

I Propose here to add a extra RTC Channel for Settings File Updates to call a reread of a settings file
so on save of a settings file we simply emit a event to that channel and vscode will reread its configuration this saves a ton of filewatchers.

we should also add a reload vscode button.

title: Clean our monospace font stack
body:
Currently it sit at:

```css
.mac { --monaco-monospace-font: "SF Mono", Monaco, Menlo, Inconsolata, "Courier New", monospace; }
.windows { --monaco-monospace-font: Consolas, Inconsolata, "Courier New", monospace; }
.linux { --monaco-monospace-font: "Droid Sans Mono", Inconsolata, "Courier New", monospace, "Droid Sans Fallback"; }
```

@bpasero Do you know where these choices come from? `Inconsolata` is rather narrow and not good for UI display. `Droid Sans Mono` isn't available on Fedora, for example, and it causes UI to fallback to use a serif font `Liberation Serif`.

IMO it should be:

```css
.mac { --monaco-monospace-font: "SF Mono", Monaco, Menlo, Courier, monospace; }
.windows { --monaco-monospace-font: Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; }
.linux { --monaco-monospace-font: "Ubuntu Mono", "Liberation Mono", "DejaVu Sans Mono", monospace; }
```

Justifications:

- `font-family: monospace` fallback chosen by Chrome:
  - Win: `Courier New`
  - macOS: `Courier`
  - Ubuntu / Fedora: `Liberation Mono`
- Ubuntu Mono is bundled in Ubuntu
- DejaVu Sans Mono is [bundled](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DejaVu_fonts) in all major distros:

    > DejaVu fonts can be obtained from the DejaVu project on GitHub. Some operating systems (OpenBSD, Solaris, Haiku, AmigaOS 4, GNU/Linux distributions such as Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, and RHEL) include DejaVu fonts in their default installation,[3][4][5][6][7] sometimes even using them as their system fonts.

- Inconsolata looks like this:

  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4033249/65921116-2cef7180-e396-11e9-8b56-91d78ddcefca.png)
  
  Normally

  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4033249/65921112-2b25ae00-e396-11e9-8bdc-bd27c2f4c3d0.png)

title: Process explorer not visible after alt-tab to VS Code
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.38.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code
2. Open process explorer
3. Alt-tab away from VS Code
4. Alt-tab back to VS Code

Expected result:
Process explorer window is visible

Actual result:
Process explorer window is hidden by VS Code main window.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Only immediate file/folder symlinks show up in Explorer panel

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.37.1
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601

I share a Windows folder i.e. ```D:\shared``` with my VirtualBox's Centos via the ```Shared Folder``` setting.
When I create symlinks inside my project folder from Centos, i.e. ```D:\shared\project```, only some of them show up in the ```Explorer panel``` of Windows VS Code. I refer to these as immediate symlinks, please see below for clearer examples.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Change folder to ```/shared/project```, i.e. ```D:\shared\project```
2. ```ln -s ../repo/ slinkfolder1``` - trying to link to ```D:\shared\repo```, a parent folder
3. ```ln -s storage/app/ slinkfolder2``` - trying to link to ```D:\shared\project\storage\app```, a child folder
4. ```ln -s storage/ slinkfolder3``` - trying to link to ```D:\shared\project\storage```, an immediate folder
5. ```slinkfolder1``` and ```slinkfolder2``` does not show up in the ```Explorer panel```, only ```slinkfolder3``` can be located

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No
Yes

title: Better Touch using

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Issue Type: Feature Request Hello, I realised it is not easy to select text on a touch screen. This is, because all touch gestures are interpreted as scrolling and not as selecting. I looked what Notepad++ does. This is very interesting. Notepad++ works differently depending on what direction the touch swiping starts. If it starts vertically (up/down) then ist is scrolling and if it starte horizontally (left/right) it is selecting. - It should be noted, that even if you start moving the finger up or down for scrolling, if the scrolling has started you still can scroll left or right. If you are in selection mode (left/right movement) you can also select up and down. So the application looks how the movement started. This is a really cool and accassible way of using touch in this program. Visual Studio code should work in a similar way. (PS: This whole way of using with touch reminds me of the clever way Tiles worked Windows 8. Unfortunately Microsoft forgot about that, when they switched scrolling direction of Tiles in Windows 10.) VS Code version: Code 1.38.1 (b37e54c98e1a74ba89e03073e5a3761284e3ffb0, 2019-09-11T13:35:15.005Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18362

title: Run filetype autodetection when text is copied into a new empty tab

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I think the following scenario can be improved:
1. User copies (Ctrl+C) text of python script from somewhere.
2. User opens a new tab in text editor
3. User pasts (Ctrl+V) the copied text into the new empty tab
4. The copied text is not getting highlighted as "Python" even though it has `#!/usr/bin/env python` as the first line. If I save the same text as "opaque_data" named file and open it in VSCode - it will successfully auto-detect it as Python code. The same detection algorithm can be triggered in case of text copy into a new **empty** buffer, and it should also trigger a special event for VSCode extensions.

title: enable strictFunctionTypes in VS Code codebase
